PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS IN MATALE DISTRICT: TECHNICAL
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government:
(i) the number of technical officers that has been approved for the public institutions in Matale District;
(ii) the number of technical officers serving at present; and
(iii) the number of vacancies existing in that position at present?
(b) Will he also inform this House -
(i) whether he admits the fact that the vacancies existing in the position of technical officer adversely affect the construction activities in Matale District; and
(ii) if so, the steps that will be taken to fill the aforesaid vacancies?

) ( - ) (The Hon. Mohamad Muzammil on behalf of the Hon. Gamini Waleboda) - (1)
asked the Minister of Trade, Commerce and Food Security:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether he is aware that converting printed books into Portable Document Format and distributing them for the purpose of gaining profits without obtaining prior permission of the authors of such books has caused a grave injustice to the authors of those books; and (ii) the steps that have been taken to curb this situation and to serve justice to the authors who have been subjected to such injustices?

(b) Will he also inform this House - (i) whether he admits that it is important to convert into Portable Document Format and conserve the books of which printed copies are not available at present; and (ii) if so, the measures that have been taken in that regard?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Prasanna Ranatunga) * .

SPECIAL STATEMENT IN PARLIAMENT BY HON. PRESIDENT
ON IMF AGREEMENT [.. 10.43] ( , , ) ( - , , ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena - Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government) . .

Today is a historic day in our Parliament, discussing details of an Agreement our country has reached with the IMF after protracted deliberations. . There is no doubt that all of us agree that at a time when all are concerned about the need to consolidate our efforts to overcome the critical state the economy of the country is in, rather unprecedented in our history, we are compelled to look at things and consider facts in a more pragmatic sense sinking all other differences. .
Amidst several obstacles from sources seen as well as unseen, they did their best to reach this much-needed
Agreement for us to have a breathing spell to restart our journey, which remained hibernated during these crisis times.

Sir, I wish to refer, in brief, to our previous experiences with IMF assistance granted from time to time since we became a member of the international institution. Some are trying to make out that what we have achieved is something unique, as if it has never happened before. With due respect, with the right to express ones own views on any matter, I wish to emphasize the importance of sticking to the realities and the need to consider the facts as they are. Diversions, deviations and misrepresentations on critical issues, sometimes, sound and appear to be rather hypocritical. I would like to just mention that during the 1960s - from 1965 to 1969 - we were granted facilities under Stand-by Arrangements on four occasions, from 1971 to 1974, assistance was provided under two Stand-by Arrangements, between 1977 and 1983, under one Stand-by Arrangement, one Extended Fund Facility and one Structural Adjustment Facility by the IMF. In September 1991, we were granted another Extended Credit Facility. Between 2001 and 2009, we had obtained four facilitations from the IMF. It should be noted that Sri Lanka has honoured and duly repaid all those facilitations and we had no outstanding dues to the IMF when we last went before them in 2016.

. During the last seven months, one of the most difficult times spent in our history, the Government, while successfully negotiating with IMF on its first tranche, made sure that they did not let any public servant or an employee of a State-owned Enterprise lose his job owing to the dire economic conditions in the country. . . . ; . . . 40 . ; . . .
. , , the Government managed, at the end of each month, to pay the salaries of the entire public sector and even to pay the pensioners.

At the same time, it is very evident that reforms are necessary for some of the State-owned Enterprises. However, any such reforms in the immediate future will be discussed with the stakeholders, especially the employees. This transparency and trust between the Government and the stakeholders is an absolute must. The President also assured that to the House in his Statement yesterday. , , . All of us in Parliament have got an opening now to restart. Let us extend our maximum possible support for that. Perhaps, it could be a critical support that is needed, but we have to anyway support this move of getting the Agreement working.

, , that during this same period, we embarked on a food security and rejuvenation programme at the grassroots in 14,000 Grama Niladhari Divisions in the 25 districts across the country. That programme, today, has shown success not only in the produce or the harvest, but importantly the differences and divisions that existed at village level before being put aside and working successfully towards overcoming a common threat or disaster.

. . . . . One step is to introduce small-scale industries or entrepreneurial programmes at village level, AGA division level and district level for economic rejuvenation. The relevant ministries, institutions and agencies of the State together with the private sector and other community organizations will collectively work towards this.
It is to empower the youth with a set of skills and knowhow required to enhance employability and

entrepreneurial capacity, which is needed both here and abroad. This programme from village level to city level across the country will train youth to be ready for better management of future economic challenges while developing better opportunities for financial stability.

People have shown, in the past six months, great financial discipline. They cut back on many unwanted expenditures, started looking for alternatives and even went to the extent of developing locally. This great habit must continue further as it will be an essential lifestyle change required for Sri Lanka to be financially disciplined and responsible. we have overcome the initial problems with regard to energy and transportation demands. Alternative schemes for logistical and energy requirements must be adopted for the greater good.
Public transportation and mass transportation are essential for a landscape where over 40 per cent of our population now lives in different urban areas.

Hydro, solar and wind are great renewable sources which are in abundance in Sri Lanka, but what is missing is that all important harnessing of those through a planned national policy, which will lead us to get rid of the unnecessary burden we are carrying.
Ideally, the strengthening of the rupee should bring more concession in prices of goods, medicines, petroleum and gas for a larger segment of the society. . . . . . .

during the last six months, 359 407.4 . . . . the IMF, the World Bank, the ADB and all other agencies will also support Sri Lanka in this effort. The countries of the Paris Club, India, China and other countries will also support us, as they have pledged.
- tourism - it should play a key role. We have noticed over 100,000 tourist arrivals this month already and the last two months ended with similar figures. This trend should be further supported.
. . 12 Swiss banks faced a crisis and therefore, they merged and found a way out. . . .

. ; . The vulnerable sections of the society, in economically turbulent times, must be looked after closely and carefully. That is being led by the Government. We have included that in the negotiations with the IMF; those were key areas. Not only the Government, but also the IMF has stressed that we should keep continuing to look after the vulnerable sections and that we should take necessary steps to support this system, which is a genuine effort. There is hope of an allowance as a support to the poorest and the elderly. ; . . . .

(, ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Nalin Fernando - Minister of Trade, Commerce and Food Security) IMF
. ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) The next speaker is the Hon. Eran Wickramaratne. You have 13 minutes.
Then, I want to quote from the IMF Country Report about the IMF's transparency policy.
The IMFs transparency policy allows for the deletion of market-sensitive information and premature disclosure of the authorities' policy intentions in published staff reports and other documents.

We can understand there being a sensitivity about market information and the need for that to be not disclosed. But, what we do not agree with is the policy regarding premature disclosure of the authorities' policy intentions. If you have policy intentions, why do you not disclose them? We argued right through that if all the 225 Hon. Members cannot be kept informed, at least they should have had an in camera session with the Public Finance Committee of Parliament and discussed about their policy intentions. That was the responsibility of the Government and they did not discharge that responsibility. So, we are critical of that disclosure policy of the IMF and I need to make that absolutely clear. The others always try to come and teach us about our disclosure polices. Therefore, at least, there could have been a debate.
Sir, we see this Report only after the President tables it in Parliament. If I were to read a few things from the Report itself, under "Context and Recent Development" in page 5 it states, I quote:
Despite progress made under the 2016-19 EFF programme,....

In other words, it states that under the earlier programme, there was progress despite the 2017 drought, the 2018 political crisis and the 2019 terrorist attacks. It further goes on to state, I quote:
Income Tax and Value Added Tax (VAT) were drastically cut in late 2019, with estimated revenue losses exceeding 2 per cent of GDP."
That was, when the new Government came in.
"The automatic fuel pricing mechanism was discontinued,....."
That, we introduced during the last period of our regime and was discontinued by this Government.
"......and legislative reforms to enhance Central Bank autonomy and fiscal rules were suspended.

A Bill dealing with the autonomy of the Central Bank had been drafted, but this Government came in and did not bring it to Parliament. And now, three years later, they are talking about bringing it to Parliament.
Then, in the same page of the Report, it states, I quote:
...usable gross international reserves declined from $7.6 billion at end-2019 to $ 1.6 billion (less than 1 month of imports) at end-2021.
This is what the IMF Report states, what the IMF is talking about as to what happened during the past period and the present period.
. . . . So, that was regarding the IMF transparency policy.

In page 107 of the IMF Country Report No. 23/116, under "Prior Actions", it states, I quote:
"Cabinet approval of Banking (Special Provisions) Act to strengthen key elements of the CBSLs crisis management powers." Also, it further states, I quote:
"Increase policy interest rates by 100 basis points to ensure forward-looking real policy rates on a firmly upward path."
In page 109, under "Personal Income Tax, Labor Income", it states, I quote:

"Introduce a progressive reform of the structure of the personal income tax (PIT) system. Set the tax-free allowance to Rs 1,200,000 per year, and raise the marginal PIT rate by 6 percentage points for every Rs 500,000 per year up to a top rate of 36 per cent."
VAT . Alsos in page 109, under "Value-Added Tax", it states, I quote:
"Raise the standard VAT rate to 15 percent.
Reduce the VAT registration threshold to Rs 80 million and apply the same threshold to the wholesale and retail sectors."
Social Security Contribution Levy . In page 110, under "Other Taxes", it states, I quote:
"Introduce a 'Social Security Contribution' on liable turnover over Rs 120 million per year at the rate of 2.5 per cent.
Introduce a fuel tax yielding 0.3 per cent of GDP."

asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government:
(i) whether he is aware that the monthly pension Mr. M. Naimullah, Pension File No. 01-802666, is entitled to is Rs.
31,833.33 according to the revised pension grant letter dated 31.12.2021;
(ii) if so, the date on which the said pension was last paid to him; and
(iii) if not paid so, the reasons for it?
(b) Will he also inform this House -

(i) the reasons why necessary measures have not yet been taken to provide the pension as stated in paragraph 3 of the letter No. ... 36/202 dated 30.10.2022 addressed to the Secretary of the Ministry of Public Administration, Home Affairs and Local Government by the Director General of Pension; and
(ii) the date on which the pension referred to in (a)(i) above along with the arrears of salary and allowances will be paid to Mr. Naimullah?
(c) If not, why? ( , , ) ( - , , ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena - Prime Minister and Minister of Public Administration, Home Affairs, Provincial Councils and Local Government)
(a) (i) 01. The pension to be paid to Mr. M.

Naimullah as at 22.11.2019, the date on which the payment should commence as per the revised pension award dated 31.12.2021, is Rs. 28,533.33. 02. As per the provisions of Public Administration Circular No. 35/2019 dated 10.12.2019, the pension is Rs. 31,833.33. (ii) The revised pension mentioned above has not been paid to date. At present, the pension paid to this officer is Rs. 13,799.99, which is the initial pension before the revision. (iii) Mr. M. Naimullah has served in seven (07) posts included in Schedule Q during the period from 12.12.2001 to 21.11.2019 with service interruptions and has submitted applications for revision of pension accordingly. Since those applications contained particulars that were not clear, after verifying the relevant particulars, the revised pension award dated 31.12.2021 was issued, and the pension file was forwarded to the Divisional Secretary, Kothmale. Accordingly, payments related to 01 of (a) (i) above will be made to the said officer in the future according to the revised pension award. (b) (i) The reason for the non-payment of the pension which should be paid to Mr. M. Naimullah as at 01.01.2020, as per the provisions of Public Administration Circular No. 03/2016, is that it has been temporarily suspended as per Public Administration Circular No. 35/2019 (I). The number of pensioners who were entitled to the revision of pension on 01.01.2020 but whose payment of that pension has been suspended is close to 99,000. Also, two cases are being heard in the Supreme Court and the Court of Appeal regarding the suspension of this payment of pension. (ii) Answers have been provided by (a) (iii) and (b) (i) above. (c) Does not arise.
Corrections which Members suggest for the Final Print of their speeches should be clearly marked in their copy and
sent to the Editor of HANSARD within two weeks of receipt of the uncorrected copy.
